title: Divorce - what happens to student loan debt
question: My spouse built up $20,000 in student loans while we lived in Tennessee. Is that debt split because of community property?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law,Spousal debt,Domestic relationships,Marriage
answers:
Student loans, generally speaking, are the obligation of the student spouse. So, if the wife goes to law school and borrows money to do it, she is benefiting from her education, and must repay the debt herself.

If the loans were "private" (non Sallie Mae, for example) and both spouses signed the loan docs, then it is not considered a separate debt. You'll need to consult an attorney in your area to determine what kind of loans yours are. Good luck!

Where do you live now? Only 10 or so states have community property, and the interpretation is purely local. Tennessee is not a community property state.

A debt that one of the parties had before the marriage usually remains the obligation of that person -- only debts contracted after marriage are usually community in nature.

What state you were married in, and what state you reside in, will be crucial in answering this question. However, in general, debts that are incurred prior to marriage will remain separate property. To get a more specific answer you should contact a family law or divorce attorney in your state.
